title: Present Tense (Presente)
explanation: Italian verbs are divided into three conjugations based on their infinitive endings: -are, -ere, -ire. Each has its own pattern.
patterns: -ARE: parlo, parli, parla, parliamo, parlate, parlano
-ERE: scrivo, scrivi, scrive, scriviamo, scrivete, scrivono
-IRE: dormo, dormi, dorme, dormiamo, dormite, dormono

title: Definite Articles (il, la, lo, l', i, le, gli)
explanation: Italian has several definite articles that change based on gender, number, and the first letter of the noun.
patterns: lo + masc. sing. before z, s+cons, gn, ps (lo studente)
gli + masc. plural before z, s+cons, vowel (gli studenti)

title: Indefinite Articles (un, una, uno, un')
explanation: Indefinite articles also change based on gender and the first letter of the noun.
patterns: uno + before z, s+cons (uno studente, uno zaino)

title: Gender of Nouns
explanation: Italian nouns are either masculine or feminine. Generally, nouns ending in -o are masculine and nouns ending in -a are feminine.
patterns: -e = can be either (il ristorante, la notte)
Exceptions: la mano (f), il problema (m), il tema (m)

title: Plural of Nouns
explanation: Italian nouns change their endings to form plurals: -o→-i, -a→-e, -e→-i.

title: Essere (to be)
explanation: Essere is an irregular verb meaning 'to be'. It's used for descriptions, nationalities, professions, and locations.

title: Avere (to have)
explanation: Avere is an irregular verb meaning 'to have'. It's also used in many expressions and to form compound tenses.

examples.english: Are you hungry? (lit: Do you have hunger?)

title: Negation with 'non'
explanation: 'Non' is placed before the verb to make negative sentences.

title: Questions
explanation: In Italian, questions can be formed simply by changing intonation (raising voice at end) or by inverting subject-verb order.
patterns: Statement with rising intonation = yes/no question
Question words: dove (where), come (how), quando (when), perché (why), cosa/che (what)

title: Prepositions: di, a, da, in, su
explanation: These basic prepositions are essential for expressing relationships, locations, and other concepts.

title: Congiuntivo Presente (Present Subjunctive)
explanation: The subjunctive mood is used to express doubt, wish, possibility, necessity, or emotions. It's often triggered by certain verbs and expressions.

examples.italian: Voglio che tu venga con me
examples.english: I want you to come with me

examples.italian: È importante che studiamo ogni giorno
examples.english: It's important that we study every day

patterns: -ARE: parli, parli, parli, parliamo, parliate, parlino
-ERE: scriva, scriva, scriva, scriviamo, scriviate, scrivano
-IRE: dorma, dorma, dorma, dormiamo, dormiate, dormano
Triggers: pensare che, credere che, volere che, sperare che, è necessario che

title: Condizionale Presente (Present Conditional)
explanation: The conditional is used to express wishes, polite requests, hypothetical situations, and what would happen under certain conditions.

examples.english: I would like a coffee, please
It would be nice to go to Italy

patterns: -ARE: parlerei, parleresti, parlerebbe, parleremmo, parlereste, parlerebbero
-ERE: scriverei, scriveresti, scriverebbe, scriveremmo, scrivereste, scriverebbero
-IRE: dormirei, dormiresti, dormirebbe, dormiremmo, dormireste, dormirebbero

title: Pronomi Relativi (Relative Pronouns)
explanation: Relative pronouns connect clauses and refer back to a noun. 'Che' is the most common, while 'cui' is used after prepositions.

examples.italian: Il libro che ho letto era interessante
examples.english: The book that I read was interesting

examples.italian: La persona di cui ti ho parlato
examples.english: The person about whom I spoke to you

examples.italian: La ragione per cui sono qui
examples.english: The reason why I am here

patterns: che = who, which, that (subject or direct object)
cui = whom, which (after prepositions: di cui, a cui, con cui, per cui)
il quale/la quale = who, which (more formal, agrees in gender/number)

exercises.question: La casa ___ ho comprato è grande.

title: Forma Passiva (Passive Voice)
explanation: The passive voice is formed with 'essere' + past participle. The agent (doer) can be introduced with 'da'.

examples.italian: La pizza è mangiata dai bambini
examples.english: The pizza is eaten by the children

examples.italian: Il libro fu scritto da Dante
examples.english: The book was written by Dante
The house will be sold soon

title: Congiuntivo Imperfetto (Imperfect Subjunctive)
explanation: Used for hypothetical situations, wishes about the past, and in subordinate clauses when the main verb is in a past tense.

examples.italian: Se avessi tempo, viaggerei di più
examples.english: If I had time, I would travel more

examples.italian: Pensavo che lui fosse più alto

examples.english: I wish you would help me

patterns: -ARE: parlassi, parlassi, parlasse, parlassimo, parlaste, parlassero
-ERE: scrivessi, scrivessi, scrivesse, scrivessimo, scriveste, scrivessero
-IRE: dormissi, dormissi, dormisse, dormissimo, dormiste, dormissero

exercises.question: Se io ___ ricco, comprerei una villa. (essere)

title: Condizionale Passato (Past Conditional)
explanation: Used to express what would have happened in the past, often in hypothetical situations with 'se' + congiuntivo trapassato.

examples.english: I would have bought that house

examples.italian: Se fossi venuto, ti avrei visto
examples.english: If you had come, I would have seen you
It would have been better to leave earlier

patterns: avere (conditional) + past participle for most verbs
essere (conditional) + past participle for movement/state verbs
Often paired with: se + congiuntivo trapassato

title: Congiunzioni Avanzate (Advanced Conjunctions)
explanation: Complex conjunctions that require the subjunctive mood and express purpose, condition, concession, or time relationships.

examples.italian: Te lo dico affinché tu sappia la verità
examples.english: I'm telling you so that you know the truth

examples.italian: Benché sia stanco, continuerò a lavorare
examples.english: Although I am tired, I will continue working

examples.italian: Prima che tu parta, devo dirti qualcosa
examples.english: Before you leave, I must tell you something

title: Discorso Indiretto (Reported Speech)
explanation: When reporting what someone said, tense shifts occur. Present becomes imperfect, passato prossimo becomes trapassato prossimo.

examples.italian: Ha detto: 'Sono stanco' → Ha detto che era stanco
examples.english: He said: 'I am tired' → He said that he was tired

examples.italian: Mi ha chiesto se volevo venire
examples.english: He asked me if I wanted to come

patterns: Passato prossimo → Trapassato prossimo: 'ho mangiato' → 'aveva mangiato'
Questions use 'se' for yes/no and question words stay

exercises.question: Marco ha detto che ___ molto stanco. (essere)

title: Passato Remoto (Remote Past)
explanation: Used in literature and formal writing to describe completed actions in the distant past. Common in Southern Italy in everyday speech.

examples.english: Dante was born in Florence in 1265

examples.italian: Visse in quella casa per vent'anni
examples.english: He lived in that house for twenty years

patterns: -ARE: parlai, parlasti, parlò, parlammo, parlaste, parlarono
-ERE: scrissi, scrivesti, scrisse, scrivemmo, scriveste, scrissero
-IRE: dormii, dormisti, dormì, dormimmo, dormiste, dormirono
Many irregular forms: fui, ebbi, dissi, feci, venne

title: Periodo Ipotetico di III Tipo (Third Conditional)
explanation: Expresses impossible conditions in the past - what would have happened if something else had happened.

examples.italian: Se fossi stato più attento, non avrei fatto quell'errore
examples.english: If I had been more careful, I wouldn't have made that mistake

examples.italian: Se avessimo preso il treno, saremmo arrivati in tempo
examples.english: If we had taken the train, we would have arrived on time

examples.italian: Non sarebbe successo se tu me lo avessi detto
examples.english: It wouldn't have happened if you had told me

patterns: Se avessi/fossi + participio passato, avrei/sarei + participio passato

exercises.question: Se ___ prima, avrei finito il lavoro. (svegliarsi)

title: Subordinate Complesse (Complex Subordinate Clauses)
explanation: Italian uses various types of subordinate clauses: relative, temporal, causal, final, consecutive, and concessive.

examples.italian: Essendo arrivato tardi, ho perso l'inizio
examples.english: Having arrived late, I missed the beginning

examples.italian: Per quanto mi sforzi, non ci riesco
examples.english: No matter how hard I try, I can't do it

examples.italian: Il libro, la cui trama è avvincente, è un bestseller
examples.english: The book, whose plot is gripping, is a bestseller

patterns: Concessive: Per quanto + congiuntivo (No matter how much)

title: Uso dei Tempi Letterari (Literary Tenses)
explanation: Literary Italian uses tenses rarely found in everyday speech, including trapassato remoto and special uses of the imperfect subjunctive.

examples.italian: Dopo che ebbe finito di parlare, se ne andò
examples.english: After he had finished speaking, he left

examples.italian: Fosse anche vero, non cambierebbe nulla
examples.english: Even if it were true, it wouldn't change anything
Let him think whatever he wanted

patterns: Trapassato remoto: ebbi/fui + participio (after che, quando, appena)
Imperfect subjunctive for wishes: 'Potessi essere lì!'

title: Variazioni Stilistiche Formali (Formal Style Variations)
explanation: Formal and bureaucratic Italian uses distinctive constructions, including impersonal 'si', passive constructions, and nominalized verbs.

examples.english: You are kindly requested not to smoke

patterns: Impersonal si: 'Si richiede che...' (It is required that...)
Archaic prepositions: all'uopo, di cui sopra, in calce

exercises.question: ___ di compilare il modulo in ogni sua parte.

title: Italiano Letterario e Poetico (Literary and Poetic Italian)
explanation: Literary Italian features archaic pronouns, inverted word order, truncated forms, and poetic licenses found in classical texts.

examples.italian: Nel mezzo del cammin di nostra vita
examples.english: In the middle of the journey of our life

examples.italian: Ché la diritta via era smarrita
examples.english: For the straight path was lost

patterns: Archaic pronouns: ei, ella, egli for lui/lei
Inverted syntax: 'Tanto gentile e tanto onesta pare'

exercises.question: '___ fu' is the famous opening of Manzoni's poem about Napoleon.

title: Costrutti Anacoluti e Dislocazioni (Anacoluthon and Dislocations)
explanation: Spoken and literary Italian often uses left/right dislocation and anacoluthon for emphasis and topic-focus structure.

examples.english: The book, I've already read it

examples.italian: A me, queste cose non piacciono
examples.english: As for me, I don't like these things

patterns: Left dislocation: Topic + clitic pronoun + verb
Anacoluthon: intentional grammatical discontinuity for effect
